title: Lloyds share sale: Osborne announces £2bn stock offer - HALF of £4bn election promise
text:
Lloyds share sale: Osborne announces £2bn stock offer - HALF of £4bn election promise Lloyds share sale: Osborne announces £2bn stock offer - HALF of £4bn election promise Around £2bn of shares in taxpayer backed Lloyds bank will be sold to the public in spring 2016 - half of the £4bn promised by the Tories in the run-up to the election. PUBLISHED: 09:58, Mon, Oct 5, 2015 | UPDATED: 12:50, Mon, Oct 5, 2015 GETTY The Tories promised £4bn of Lloyds shares would be sold to the public 
Shares will be made available to retail investors next year with a 5 per cent discount off their market price, George Osborne announced today. But the smaller than expected sale means that demand is now far expected to outstrip supply. The Government today said people buying less than £1,000 worth of stock would be prioritised. Investors will also be awarded a bonus share for every 10 purchased if they hold their investment for more than a year - capped at £200 per investor.The Tories promised that up to £4bn worth of shares would be made available to the public if they were voted back into power. But less than six months after the election, Mr Osborne has disappointed by signalling that around £2bn would be made available. GETTY The Government pumped £20bn into Lloyds at the height of financial crisis GETTY George Osborne has announced only £2bn of Lloyds shares are to be made available to the public Related articles Lloyds to pay even MORE for PPI taking shamed British banks' total... 
The sale is the final and only offering in the bank to be made to ordinary people. Around £15bn has already been sold off to faceless private banks and huge investment companies to reduce the taxpayer's holding in the bank to below 12 per cent.The Government pumped more than £20 billion into Lloyds in a bid to prop up the bank at the height of the financial crisis.Now almost all of the taxpayer's £20bn stake in the bank is set to be sold - at a discount - to fat cat institutional investors.Speaking on ITV1's Good Morning Britain, Mr Osborne today said: "We are selling Lloyds shares to members of the public, people watching this programme, small investors, people who are going to have a chance to get something back having put all that money in under the last Labour government." 
The sale is expected to be particularly popular among small investors, especially as dividends from the bank look set to increase . 
Laith Khalaf, senior analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said:"‘Wild horses couldn’t drag investors away from this share sale, especially given the discounted price and the dividend stream Lloyds is expected to start churning out. "Pensioners in particular are likely to respond to a trusted high street brand with a decent yield when interest rates are so low." 
He added: "Lloyds used to be a dividend giant in the FTSE 100 before the financial crisis and now, after years in the wilderness, the bank has started to pay a dividend again and is expected to yield 3.5 per cent this year and 5 per cent in 2016." 
Investors who apply for Lloyds shares within an ISA or Self-Invested Personal Pension (SIPP) will be able to shield payouts from income tax, and profits will be free from capital gains tax too. 
More details about the share sale are expected to be made in the coming months, with interested investors able to sign up for email alerts here . Related articles
